content:
“lass="word-wrap-span">WORKING lass="word-wrap-span">NINE to five, what a way to make a living,” lass="word-wrap-span">Dolly Parton sang in her 1980 hit. “lass="word-wrap-span">Barely getting by, it’s all taking and no giving.” lass="word-wrap-span">The country-music singer lass="word-wrap-span">bemoaned lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">daily lass="word-wrap-span">grind in her chart-topping anlass="word-wrap-span">Them. lass="word-wrap-span">But it was an optimistic time for lass="word-wrap-span">WORKING women in lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">America. lass="word-wrap-span">Laws outlass="word-wrap-span">Lawing lass="word-wrap-span">discrimination against pregnant workers and greater access to birth control helped pave lass="word-wrap-span">The way for millions of women to join lass="word-wrap-span">The workforce in lass="word-wrap-span">The 1960s and 1970s. By 1980, lass="word-wrap-span">The share of lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">American “prime-age” women—those between 25 and 54–who were eilass="word-wrap-span">Ther lass="word-wrap-span">WORKING or looking for work topped lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">equivalent figure in Canada, Australia, lass="word-wrap-span">France, lass="word-wrap-span">Germany and lass="word-wrap-span">Japan.

By the time Ms Parton’s song went platinum in 2017, all of these countries had surpassed lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">America on this measure. lass="word-wrap-span">Indeed, lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">America has the lass="word-wrap-span">dubious lass="word-wrap-span">distinction of being the only G7 country that has gone lass="word-wrap-span">backwards on this measure over the past two decades. In 1999 77% of prime-age lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">American women were part of the labour force, according to the OECD, a club of mostly rich countries—on a par with lass="word-wrap-span">Germany and lass="word-wrap-span">Britain. In 2018, this figure had slipped by two percentage points, to 75%. In the same period, Australia saw an increase of more than nine percentage points; lass="word-wrap-span">Germany a rise of six. lass="word-wrap-span">Britain, Canada and lass="word-wrap-span">France all climbed by two percentage points.

lass="word-wrap-span">The reversal in lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">America can be lass="word-wrap-span">attributed in part to a lack of female-friendly labour policies. In lass="word-wrap-span">The 1980s and 1990s, as rich countries in lass="word-wrap-span">Europe passed legislation improving conditions for working women—including laws guaranteeing equal pay, maternity leave, access to child care and more flexible work arrangements—lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">America sat on its hands. In 2015 lass="word-wrap-span">The country ranked 33rd out of 36 rich countries on public spending for families, according to lass="word-wrap-span">The OECD. lass="word-wrap-span">Tolass="word-wrap-span">day it is lass="word-wrap-span">The only developed country not to guarantee paid leave to new molass="word-wrap-span">Thers.

lass="word-wrap-span">Bringing lass="word-wrap-span">More women into lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">America’s workforce would yield economic benefits. A study published in 2012 by Booz Allen lass="word-wrap-span">Hamilton, a lass="word-wrap-span">consultancy, lass="word-wrap-span">estimated that increasing the labour-force participation of lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">American women to that of men would boost output by 5%. It would lass="word-wrap-span">alleviate the problem of an ageing population, too. A decade ago, there were roughly five working-age lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">Americans for every one of retirement age; by 2020, the lass="word-wrap-span">Census lass="word-wrap-span">Bureau reckons, there will be just three and a half. lass="word-wrap-span">More women doing the nine-to-five would help ease this lass="word-wrap-span">demographic lass="word-wrap-span">crunch.

n. 法律；规律；法学；定律
网络 法则；法学院
eg2: If they entered the building they would be breaking the law .
如果进入那栋大楼，他们就会触犯法律。
In Sweden it is against the law to hit a child.
在瑞典打小孩是违法的。
Defence attorneys can use any means within the law to get their client off.
辩护律师可在法律许可的范围内利用任何手段为当事人脱罪。
British schools are now required by law to publish their exam results.
现在英国的学校得按法律规定公布考试结果。
The reforms have recently become law .
这些改革最近已成为法律。
Do not think you are above the law(= think that you cannot be punished by the law) .
别以为你能凌驾于法律之上。
the need for better law enforcement
加强执法力度的必要
Kate's word was law in the Brown household.
凯特的话在布朗家就是金科玉律。
company/international/tax, etc. law
公司法、国际法、税法等
the 1996 law against the hiring of illegal immigrants
禁止雇用非法移民的 1996 法规
The government has introduced some tough new laws on food hygiene.
政府对食物卫生出台了一些强硬的新法规。
strict gun laws
严格的枪支法
a federal/state law
联邦法律；州法律
to pass a law(= officially make it part of the system of laws)
通过一项法律
There ought to be a law against it!
应该立法加以禁止！
Jane is studying law.
简正在学习法律。
He's in law school .
他在读法学院。
He's at law school.
他在读法学院。
What made you go into law?
是什么促使你从事法律行业的呢？
a law firm
律师事务所

moral laws

the unspoken laws of the street

the laws of supply and demand

the law of gravity

the first law of thermodynamics

wp.alleviate e: 减轻;缓和;使易于忍受;在痛苦方面的减轻

ex: vt. 减轻，缓和
eg2: In this article, you have learned how to alleviate some of the restrictions and problems that developers unknowingly create for their consumers during development time.
在本文中，您了解了如何减轻开发人员在进行开发时不知不觉为用户制造的一些限制和问题。
He not only feels a sorrow of the same kind with that which they feel, but as if he had derived a part of it to himself, what he feels seems to  the weight of what they feel.
说倾听者和他们一起分担忧愁似乎不大合适，他不仅和他们一样感觉到了悲伤，而且似乎在他们的心理负担减轻了之后，自己又得到了一些悲伤。
An organic weariness drives the nerves and the flesh to a despair that only an exploration of all forms of pleasure can .
有机的疲倦驾驭着神经与肉体驶向绝望——一种只有通过对各种形式愉快的探索才能减轻的绝望。

wp.Gaslight Anthem: 煤气灯圣歌乐队;表演者

ex: n. 赞美诗；圣歌
vt. 唱圣歌庆祝；唱赞歌
eg2: It's ironic that Korman had her father and her children dance to this classic gay .
比较嘲讽的是科曼和她父亲还有孩子伴着这首经典的同志圣歌跳舞。
He mentioned a Palestinian state only once and at other times talked only of areas under Palestinian control, saying the Palestinians could have their own "flag,  and administration".
在讲演中，他仅一次提到巴勒斯坦国，其余时间只是使用“巴勒斯坦控制下的地区”这一说法。 他称巴勒斯坦可以拥有自己的“国旗、国歌和政府” 。
Initially officials were going to play the Austrian anthem but then realised that Australia and Austria were not the same country.
最初，官员们打算播放奥地利国歌，后来意识到，澳大利亚和奥地利是两个不同的国家。

每个级别都应该有一个标题属性。

要完成这项任务，应该首先确定这个属性出现在哪个元素上。

从这些标记中，我们可以看出类名和每个属性的名字与类型。

ex: adj. 向后的；反向的；发展迟缓的

eg2: He cut the ball so that it bounded almost .
他斜削这个球，使其几乎向后弹起。
Browse diagrams keep a history of the views it displays so that you can navigate forward and backward from each view.
浏览图可以保持它所显示视图的历史记录，因此您可以从任何一个视图向前或者向后导航。
But once you actually do jump backward in time, you still seem to have a choice about what to do next.
而一旦你确实及时地向后跳了，仍然会面对下一步要做什么的选择。

ex: vt. 惋惜；为…恸哭
vi. 叹息
eg2: He used the meetings as occasions to  the treatment of women in the West.
他以这些会面为契机，表达自己对妇女在西方待遇的不满。
Again and again last week I heard Chinese officials  the failure of the west to lead by example on tackling emissions.
上个星期，我听到中国官员一再对西方没有在处理排放问题方面以身作则表示惋惜。
All ye that are about him,  him; and all ye that know his name, say, How is the strong staff broken, and the beautiful rod!
凡在她四围的和认识她名的，你们都要为她悲伤，说，那结实的杖和那美好的棍，何竟折断了呢。

eg2: The administration's policy seems to  the economy in order to combat inflation.
政府的政策似乎是紧缩经济以免通货膨胀。
We have good intentions and plan to come back after the time  at hand subsides, but we seldom do that.
当紧迫的时间稍微缓和之后，我们应该有很好的目的和计划返回来检查，但是我们却很少这样做。
But when all those factors are put together and the economists crunch the numbers, it ends up being a net positive, but a small one.
“但当所有那些因素放在一起并且经济学家处理了大量数字时，它最终的结局是确实有一点，但很小的一点”。
